channel.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
channel.description:
So yeah, started on fixing up my old car since it's basically a wreck.
Battery is fine, swapped it over to another car of mine and ran it up. tried the other cars battery on the clio and it didn't even spin the starter.
Checked the cables going to the starter solonoid (usually on clios its got a problem with the white going in and usually needs switch cleaner) so i sanded it down and put switch cleaner on it but yet again fuck all happened.
Tried bumping, jumping and these are to no avail - just ripped out the starter and am going to get another in a while for it - was thinking alternator but i'll check that one out after the starter, also maybe it's the key fob - people who are used to clios could be aware that if the key fob battery runs low then the immobiliser just fucks the cars starting up.
x x x ideas x x x do it x x x

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:343730”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=440120.msg3239288#msg3239288 date=1276764893]

As for the starter it looks in perfect condition from a first glance (Haven’t had time to strip it yet), but the teeth are fine and it doesn’t seem to be burnt out at all.

^^^
[/quote]

You can’t tell if a starter is in good working order by looking at it.[/quote]

LoL

Read full topic

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:9, topic:343730”]well theres three things if it doesnt actually turn over,

the battery must have enough charge,
the starter motor must be OK,
and the starter circuit should be in working order[/quote]

Exactly, he has checked whether the battery has enough charge, he has checked the fuses. He needs to check the starter itself as per my instructions.

Read full topic

spark plugs?

Changed the sparks, HT and coil not a month ago and have ran it up every day since then until maybe a week ago.

item.source: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

well theres three things if it doesnt actually turn over,

the battery must have enough charge,
the starter motor must be OK,
and the starter circuit should be in working order

if its none of those, check the fuel is being supplied to the engine cylinders.

then, check the spark plugs… ^^

Read full topic
item.source: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Cowie`, post:6, topic:343730”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=440120.msg3237608#msg3237608 date=1276619885]
You can take the starter to an auto parts store and have it checked for free, around here anyway. If you can’t you can CAREFULLY do it with a set of jumper cables hooked up to the battery, but the ground cable on the starter housing, the positive cable on the solenoid where the positive cable would go on a car, then using a screwdriver or something else jump between the two terminals on the solenoid (the big one where the cable is attached and the much smaller, actuator one.

If it runs, the solenoid and starter are good. If it doesn’t, bypass the solenoid by removing the positive cable from it, and touching it to the wire or strap that goes from the solenoid directly into the starter. If the starter runs then the solenoid is bad, if it doesn’t the starter is bad.

If the starter is good, then you have a cable problem, a switch problem, or if the car is so equipped some fancy computer stopping it from turning over. The first thing you should check regardless is for blown fuses, it’s obvious but easily overlooked, we have all done it.
[/quote]

Checked the fuses first, and as I said usually with the renault key fob if it’s running low on battery the immobiliser doesn’t allow the engine to run.

As for the starter it looks in perfect condition from a first glance (Haven’t had time to strip it yet), but the teeth are fine and it doesn’t seem to be burnt out at all.

Needs ideass[/quote]
You don’t have to strip it, just check the starter like I said with jumper cables.

@ollie, if it isn’t turning over then spark plugs can’t be the problem.

Read full topic
item.source: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:343730”]You can take the starter to an auto parts store and have it checked for free, around here anyway. If you can’t you can CAREFULLY do it with a set of jumper cables hooked up to the battery, but the ground cable on the starter housing, the positive cable on the solenoid where the positive cable would go on a car, then using a screwdriver or something else jump between the two terminals on the solenoid (the big one where the cable is attached and the much smaller, actuator one.

If it runs, the solenoid and starter are good. If it doesn’t, bypass the solenoid by removing the positive cable from it, and touching it to the wire or strap that goes from the solenoid directly into the starter. If the starter runs then the solenoid is bad, if it doesn’t the starter is bad.

If the starter is good, then you have a cable problem, a switch problem, or if the car is so equipped some fancy computer stopping it from turning over. The first thing you should check regardless is for blown fuses, it’s obvious but easily overlooked, we have all done it. :)[/quote]

Checked the fuses first, and as I said usually with the renault key fob if it’s running low on battery the immobiliser doesn’t allow the engine to run.

As for the starter it looks in perfect condition from a first glance (Haven’t had time to strip it yet), but the teeth are fine and it doesn’t seem to be burnt out at all.

Needs ideass

Read full topic

item.source: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue

item.title: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can take the starter to an auto parts store and have it checked for free, around here anyway. If you can’t you can CAREFULLY do it with a set of jumper cables hooked up to the battery, but the ground cable on the starter housing, the positive cable on the solenoid where the positive cable would go on a car, then using a screwdriver or something else jump between the two terminals on the solenoid (the big one where the cable is attached and the much smaller, actuator one.

If it runs, the solenoid and starter are good. If it doesn’t, bypass the solenoid by removing the positive cable from it, and touching it to the wire or strap that goes from the solenoid directly into the starter. If the starter runs then the solenoid is bad, if it doesn’t the starter is bad.

If the starter is good, then you have a cable problem, a switch problem, or if the car is so equipped some fancy computer stopping it from turning over. The first thing you should check regardless is for blown fuses, it’s obvious but easily overlooked, we have all done it.

Read full topic
item.source: X Reg Clio grande 1.2 starting issue

x x x ideas x x x do it x x x
